items.title: macOS 26 Tahoe: The Ars Technica Review
items.standfirst: Liquid Glass brings translucent sheen to the typical batch of iterative changes.
items.content: The last time Apple gave macOS a fresh design was in 2020's macOS 11 Big Sur. That release was relatively light on new features and heavy on symbolism. Big Sur is also when Apple finally jettisoned the "10" in Mac OS X after two decades. More importantly, it was the first release installed on then-new Apple Silicon Macs, the culmination of a decade-plus of in-house chip design that began with single-core, low-power iPhone and iPad chips and culminated in something powerful enough for the Mac Pro. Today's macOS 26 Tahoe release holds up a translucent, glassy mirror to the Big Sur update. It comes with an all-new look, one that further unifies Apple's design language across all its operating systems. And it even throws out the old version numbering system and introduces a new one.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: macOS 26 Tahoe introduces "Liquid Glass" design changes.
The review notes small usability and accessibility regressions.

Apple last updated macOS design in 2020 with Big Sur.
The review is from Ars Technica.

clusters.title: China says Nvidia violated antitrust regulations
clusters.neutral_headline: China says Nvidia violated antitrust regulations: China is investigating Nvidia's 2020 acquisition of Mellanox Technologies as trade tensions between the U.S. and China heat up

items.title: China says Nvidia violated antitrust regulations
items.standfirst: China is investigating Nvidia's 2020 acquisition of Mellanox Technologies as trade tensions between the U.S. and China heat up.
items.content: China is investigating Nvidia's 2020 acquisition of Mellanox Technologies as trade tensions between the U.S. and China heat up.

items.title: China rules that Nvidia violated its antitrust laws
items.standfirst: Regulator’s statement comes as US and Chinese officials meet in Madrid for trade talks.
items.content: A Chinese regulator has found Nvidia violated the country’s antitrust law, in a preliminary finding against the world’s most valuable chipmaker. Nvidia had failed to fully comply with provisions outlined when it acquired Mellanox Technologies, an Israeli-US supplier of networking products, China’s State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) said on Monday. Beijing conditionally approved the US chipmaker’s acquisition of Mellanox in 2020. Monday’s statement came as US and Chinese officials prepared for more talks in Madrid over trade, with a tariff truce between the world’s two largest economies set to expire in November.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: China is investigating Nvidia for antitrust violations.
The investigation concerns Nvidia's acquisition of Mellanox.
The acquisition occurred in 2020.
Trade tensions between the US and China are increasing.
The regulator's statement follows trade talks in Madrid.

clusters.title: Boeing faces $3.1M fine for door plug blowout, hundreds of safety violations
clusters.neutral_headline: Boeing Faces Fine for Door Plug Blowout, Safety Violations

items.title: Boeing faces $3.1M fine for door plug blowout, hundreds of safety violations
items.standfirst: FAA found factory violations, says Boeing sought approval for unairworthy planes.
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration on Friday proposed fines of $3.1 million against Boeing for various safety violations related to the January 2024 door plug blowout and what the FAA called "interference with safety officials' independence." An FAA statement said the proposed fine covers "safety violations that occurred from September 2023 through February 2024," and is the "maximum statutory civil penalty authority consistent with law." Boeing, which reported $22.7 billion in revenue and a net loss of $612 million last quarter, has 30 days to file a response with the agency. "The FAA identified hundreds of quality system violations at Boeing's 737 factory in Renton, Washington, and Boeing subcontractor Spirit AeroSystems' 737 factory in Wichita, Kansas. Additionally, Boeing presented two unairworthy aircraft to the FAA for airworthiness certificates and failed to follow its quality system," the FAA said.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Boeing faces a $3.1 million fine.
The fine is related to a door plug blowout.
The FAA found factory violations.
Boeing sought approval for unairworthy planes.
The article focuses on safety violations.

clusters.title: Will TikTok go dark Wednesday? Trump claims deal with China avoids shutdown.
clusters.neutral_headline: Will TikTok go dark Wednesday? Trump claims deal with China avoids shutdown

items.title: Will TikTok go dark Wednesday? Trump claims deal with China avoids shutdown.
items.standfirst: Experts aren’t sure China will agree to a sale without more trade war concessions.
items.content: Once again, the Trump administration is hyping a deal that could see TikTok finally sold to US owners to avoid a nationwide ban that Congress successfully argued was otherwise necessary to protect national security. On Monday, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed that the US and China had ironed out a "framework" for the deal, but ultimately, Donald Trump will be responsible for closing the deal on a call this Friday with China's president, Xi Jinping, CNBC reported. Critically, Bessent said that the framework pointed to a "switch to US-controlled ownership," the South China Morning Post (SCMP) reported. Presumably, TikTok won't shut down ahead of Trump's call with Xi, but TikTok risked going dark as soon as Wednesday. That's the latest deadline for the forced sale after Trump extended the deadline three times as negotiations with China remained tense.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: There is uncertainty about TikTok's future.
The former US president claims a deal avoids shutdown.
Experts are unsure China will agree to a sale.
The sale would require trade war concessions.
The article focuses on the potential shutdown.

clusters.title: Get into the cockpit as new crop of “Top Gun” pilots get their wings
clusters.neutral_headline: New Documentary Shows "Top Gun" Pilots Training

items.title: Get into the cockpit as new crop of “Top Gun” pilots get their wings
items.standfirst: NatGeo's new documentary series, Top Guns: The Next Generation, shows the sweat behind the spectacle.
items.content: The blockbuster success of the 1986 film Top Gun—chronicling the paths of young naval aviators as they go through the grueling US Navy's Fighter Weapons School (aka the titular Top Gun)—spawned more than just a successful multimedia franchise. It has also been credited with inspiring future generations of fighter pilots. National Geographic takes viewers behind the scenes to see the process play out for real, with its new documentary series, Top Guns: The Next Generation. Each episode focuses on a specific aspect of the training, following a handful of students from the Navy and Marines through the highs and lows of their training. That includes practicing dive bombs at break-neck speeds; successfully landing on an aircraft carrier by "catching the wire"; learning the most effective offensive and defensive maneuvers in dogfighting; and, finally, engaging in a freestyle dogfight against a seasoned instructor to complete the program and (hopefully) earn their golden wings. NatGeo was granted unprecedented access, even using in-cockpit cameras to capture the pulse-pounding action of being in the air, as well as capturing behind-the-scenes candid moments. How does reality stack up against its famous Hollywood depiction? "I think there is a lot of similarity," Capt. Juston "Poker" Kuch, who oversees all training and operations at NAS Meridian, told Ars. "The execution portion of the mission gets focused in the movie so it is all about the flight and the dogfighting and dropping the bombs. What they don't see is the countless hours of preparation that go into the mission, all the years and years of training that it took to get there. You see the battle scenes in Top Gun and you're inspired, but there's a lot of time and effort that goes in to get an individual to that point. It doesn't make for good movies, I guess."Read full article Comments

ai_summary: A new documentary series, "Top Guns: The Next Generation," follows pilot training.
The series is produced by National Geographic.
It provides a look at the rigorous training behind the spectacle of flight.
The documentary aims to show the dedication of the pilots.
Viewers will see the challenges and triumphs of aspiring pilots.

clusters.title: Parts shortage is the latest problem to hit General Motors production
clusters.neutral_headline: General Motors Faces Production Issues Due to Parts Shortage

items.title: Parts shortage is the latest problem to hit General Motors production
items.standfirst: There will be temporary layoffs at a factory in Missouri from September 29–October 19.
items.content: General Motors will temporarily lay off workers at its Wentzville assembly plant in Missouri. According to a letter sent to employees by the head of the plant and the head of the local union, a shortage of parts is the culprit, and as a result, the factory will see "a temporary layoff from September 29–October 19." The plant is about 45 minutes west of St. Louis and employs more than 4,000 people to assemble midsize pickup trucks for Chevrolet and GMC, as well as full-size vans. Not every employee will be laid off—"skilled trades, stamping, body shop, final process and those groups that support these departments" may still have work. Government policies Earlier this month, GM revealed plans to reduce the number of electric vehicles it builds, despite having a bumper month in August that saw it sell very nearly twice as many EVs as Ford. In that case, it blamed weak demand for electric vehicles, no doubt forecasting what the end of the IRS clean vehicle tax credit will do to the market.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: General Motors is experiencing production problems.
A parts shortage is the primary cause of the issues.
Temporary layoffs will occur at a Missouri factory.
The layoffs are scheduled from September 29 to October 19.
The situation highlights supply chain vulnerabilities.

clusters.title: NASA closing its original repository for Columbia artifacts to tours
clusters.neutral_headline: NASA Closing Columbia Artifact Repository to Tours

items.title: NASA closing its original repository for Columbia artifacts to tours
items.standfirst: A reminder to remain diligent and keep focused on safety.
items.content: NASA is changing the way that its employees come in contact with, and remember, one of its worst tragedies. In the wake of the 2003 loss of the space shuttle Columbia and its STS-107 crew, NASA created a program to use the orbiter's debris for research and education at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Agency employees were invited to see what remained of the space shuttle as a powerful reminder as to why they had to be diligent in their work. Access to the Columbia Research and Preservation Office, though, was limited as a result of its location and related logistics. To address that and open up the experience to more of the workforce at Kennedy, the agency has quietly begun work to establish a new facility.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: NASA is closing its original repository for Columbia artifacts.
The closure is a reminder of the importance of safety.
The focus should remain on diligence and safety protocols.
The decision impacts public access to historical artifacts.
The move may be related to preservation efforts.
